sourceDesc:
<<<<<<< HEAD
The Quakers looking-glass look'd upon; and turned toward himself; in a sober reply to an uncivll [sic] pamplet published by Luke Howard a Quaker, against a narrative formerly published, setting forth the folly and presumption of Charles Baily a Quaker, sometimes a prisoner in Dover ... Hobbs, Richard, 17th cent.
13 [i.e. 15] p.
Printed for Francis Smith at the Elephant and Castle ..., London : 1673.
"To the reader" signed: Richard Hobbs. Numerous errors in paging. Reproduction of original in: Friends' Library (London, England).
=======
The Quakers looking-glass look'd upon; and turned toward himself; in a sober reply to an uncivll [sic] pamplet published by Luke Howard a Quaker, against a narrative formerly published, setting forth the folly and presumption of Charles Baily a Quaker, sometimes a prisoner in Dover ... Hobbs, Richard, 17th cent.
13 [i.e. 15] p.
Printed for Francis Smith at the Elephant and Castle ..., London : 1673.
"To the reader" signed: Richard Hobbs. Numerous errors in paging. Reproduction of original in: Friends' Library (London, England).
Francis Smith
the Elephant
